We consider an FL system in a HieIoT network consisting of a set â„³â‰œ{v1,â€¦,vM}â‰œâ„³subscriptğ‘£1â€¦subscriptğ‘£ğ‘€{\cal M}\triangleq\{v_{1},\ldots,v_{M}\} of Mğ‘€M RCs (i.e., clients registered at the FL platform) and a set of ğ’©â‰œ{v1,â€¦,vN}â‰œğ’©subscriptğ‘£1â€¦subscriptğ‘£ğ‘{\cal N}\triangleq\{v_{1},\ldots,v_{N}\} of Nğ‘N UnRCs.
The set of all RCs and UnRCs is denoted by ğ’±â‰œ{v1,v2,â€¦,v|ğ’±|}â‰œğ’±subscriptğ‘£1subscriptğ‘£2â€¦subscriptğ‘£ğ’±{\cal V}\triangleq\{v_{1},v_{2},\ldots,v_{|{\cal V}|}\} and |ğ’±|=M+N.ğ’±ğ‘€ğ‘|{\cal V}|=M+N.
The FL server first broadcast the information of a FL job to all RCs, but it does not have access to the information of UnRCs.
Moreover, the trust among clients can be established through SIoTs such as WeChat, Twitter, and Facebook, etc., so the trust remains unchanged for a long time.
In addition, without loss of generality, we assume that for each UnRC vnâˆˆğ’©subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›ğ’©v_{n}\in{\cal N}, there exists at least one RC (vmâˆˆâ„³subscriptğ‘£ğ‘šâ„³v_{m}\in{\cal M}) having a social relationship with the UnRC.
This assumption is reasonable because if there is no trust value from any RC to UnRC vnâˆˆğ’©subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›ğ’©v_{n}\in{\cal N}, then vnsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘›v_{n} will not be recommended by RCs (i.e., it will not participate in any task).
In this context, we first remove this type of UnRCs when implementing LRef-FedCS.
Denote by ğ‘¾=[wm,n]âˆˆâ„MÃ—Nğ‘¾delimited-[]subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘šğ‘›superscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘{\boldsymbol{W}}=[w_{m,n}]\in{\mathbb{R}}^{M\times N} the trust matrix with entries wm,nâˆˆ[0,1]subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘šğ‘›01w_{m,n}\in[0,1] representing the trust value between RC vmsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘šv_{m} and UnRC vnsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘›v_{n}, where wm,n=0subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘šğ‘›0w_{m,n}=0 means vmsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘šv_{m} and vnsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘›v_{n} are strangers and wm,nâˆˆ(0,1]subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘šğ‘›01w_{m,n}\in(0,1] otherwise.
The key notation definitions are summarized in Table I.

Based on the communication phase described in Section V.A, it is necessary to carefully configure the simulation parameters.
First, we consider a wireless FL with carrier frequency 2.3â€‹Â GHz2.3Â GHz2.3\text{~{}GHz} and bandwidth 0.2â€‹Â MHz.0.2Â MHz0.2\text{~{}MHz}.
We set the path loss exponents for each individual link and the path loss at the reference distance 1â€‹Â m1Â m1\text{~{}m} to be 333 and 303030 dBm, respectively, and adopt Rayleigh fading to reproduce multipath effects [27].
We assume that perfect channel information is known at the receivers pilot signals [27].
Throughout the simulations, unless otherwise specified, we adopt the parameters reported in Table II, where, for simplicity, each UnRC is assumed to have the same long-term QoS requirement, i.e., Rminc2csuperscriptsubscriptğ‘…c2cR_{\min}^{\text{c2c}}, and each potential participant is also assumed to have the same computation time constraint in one local iteration, i.e., TmaxcmpsuperscriptsubscriptTcmp\text{T}_{\max}^{\text{cmp}}.
Moreover, all the RCs are assumed to have the same CPU frequency fm=frcsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘“rcf_{m}=f_{\text{rc}} and transmit power budget pmmax=prcmaxsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘rcp_{m}^{\max}=p_{\text{rc}}^{\max}.
Likewise, the same CPU frequency fn=furcsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›subscriptğ‘“urcf_{n}=f_{\text{urc}} and the maximum transmit power pnmax=purcmaxsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘urcp_{n}^{\max}=p_{\text{urc}}^{\max} are imposed for all UnRCs.
In addition, we set Î»t=1/6superscriptğœ†ğ‘¡16\lambda^{t}={1}/{6} and Î»e=5/6superscriptğœ†ğ‘’56\lambda^{e}={5}/{6}.
